info.name: RudderStack API
info.description: Detailed documentation of all the supported RudderStack APIs.

item.name: HTTP API

request.description:
The `identify` call lets you capture the relevant details about a visitor user and also record any traits associated with them.

> As a best practice, make sure the `identify` call is made at the start of every session or page load for logged-in users. This will ensure all the latest user traits are captured.
----

#### Accepted Fields

|**Field**|**Type**|**Presence**|**Description**|
|-----|-----|-----|-----|
|`anonymousId`|String|Optional|Sets the user ID in cases where there is no unique identifier for the user in the database.|
|`userId`|String|Optional, if `anonymousId` is set.|Unique identifier for a particular user in your database.|
|`context`|Object|Optional|Dictionary of information that provides additional context about the message. It is not directly related to the API call.|
|`integrations`|Object|Optional|Contains the list of destinations to be enabled or disabled.|
|`timestamp`|Date|Optional|The timestamp associated with the user's arrival.|
|`traits`|Object|Optional|Dictionary of the user traits such as `name` or `email`.|

The `track` call lets you record all the user actions along with their associated properties. 

> Each user action is considered to be an event.
----

#### Accepted Fields

|**Field**|**Type**|**Presence**|**Description**|
|-----|-----|-----|-----|
|`anonymousId`|String|Optional|Sets the user ID in cases where there is no unique identifier for the user in the database.|
|`userId`|String|Optional, if `anonymousId` is set.|Unique identifier for a particular user in your database.|
|`context`|Object|Optional|Dictionary of information that provides additional context about the message. It is not directly related to the API call.|
|`event`|String|Required|Name of the user event.|
|`properties`|Object|Optional|Dictionary of the properties associated with the particular event.|
|`integrations`|Object|Optional|Contains the list of destinations to be enabled or disabled.|
|`timestamp`|Date|Optional|The timestamp associated with the user's arrival.|

The `page` call lets you record your website's page views along with any additional relevant information about the viewed page.

#### Accepted Fields

|**Field**|**Type**|**Presence**|**Description**|
|-----|-----|-----|-----|
|`anonymousId`|String|Optional|Sets the user ID in cases where there is no unique identifier for the user in the database.|
|`userId`|String|Optional, if `anonymousId` is set.|Unique identifier for a particular user in your database.|
|`context`|Object|Optional|Dictionary of information that provides additional context about the message. It is not directly related to the API call.|
|`integrations`|Object|Optional|Contains the list of destinations to be enabled or disabled.|
|`name`|String|Required|Name of the viewed page.|
|`properties`|Object|Optional|Dictionary of the user traits such as `url`, `referrer`, etc.|
|`timestamp`|Date|Optional|The timestamp associated with the user's arrival.|

The `screen` call lets you record whenever a mobile app user sees the screen of their mobile device. This call is the `page` equivalent for a mobile app/device.

#### Accepted Fields

|**Field**|**Type**|**Presence**|**Description**|
|-----|-----|-----|-----|
|`anonymousId`|String|Optional|Sets the user ID in cases where there is no unique identifier for the user in the database.|
|`userId`|String|Optional, if `anonymousId` is set.|Unique identifier for a particular user in your database.|
|`context`|Object|Optional|Dictionary of information that provides additional context about the message. It is not directly related to the API call.|
|`integrations`|Object|Optional|Contains the list of destinations to be enabled or disabled.|
|`name`|String|Required|Name of the screen being viewed by the user.|
|`timestamp`|Date|Optional|The timestamp associated with the user's arrival.|
|`properties`|Object|Optional|Dictionary of the properties associated with the screen, such as `url`,`referrer`, etc.|

The `group` call lets you associate an identified user with a group such as a company, organization, or an account.

It also allows you to record any traits associated with that group such as the name of the company, industry, or the number of employees in the organization.

#### Accepted Fields

|**Field**|**Type**|**Presence**|**Description**|
|-----|-----|-----|-----|
|`anonymousId`|String|Optional|Sets the user ID in cases where there is no unique identifier for the user in the database.|
|`userId`|String|Optional, if `anonymousId` is set.|Unique identifier for a particular user in your database.|
|`groupId`|String|Required|Unique identifier for the particular group in your database.|
|`context`|Object|Optional|Dictionary of information that provides additional context about the message. It is not directly related to the API call.|
|`traits`|Object|Optional|Dictionary of the user traits such as `name` or `email`.|
|`integrations`|Object|Optional|Contains the list of destinations to be enabled or disabled.|
|`timestamp`|Date|Optional|The timestamp associated with the user's arrival.|

The `alias` call captures any relevant details about the user's alternate/past identity. With `alias`, you can merge or associate a user's past identity with the current one. 

The `alias` call is quite useful in cases where you need to associate an `anonymousId` with an identified user on signup (in case of Mixpanel) or associating user identities when the user switches their IDs (in case of Kissmetrics).

#### Accepted Fields

|**Field**|**Type**|**Presence**|**Description**|
|-----|-----|-----|-----|
|`userId`|String|Optional|Sets the user ID in cases where there is no unique identifier for the user in the database.|
|`previousId`|String|Required|The previous unique identifier of the user.|
|`context`|Object|Optional|Dictionary of information that provides additional context about the message. It is not directly related to the API call.|
|`integrations`|Object|Optional|Contains the list of destinations to be enabled or disabled.|
|`timestamp`|Date|Optional|The timestamp associated with the message's arrival.|
|`traits`|Object|Optional|Dictionary of the user traits such as `name` or `email`.|

The `batch` call lets you send a series of `identify`, `track`, `page`, `group`, and `screen` requests in a single batch. This call helps you minimize the number of outbound requests, thus enabling better performance.

> **RudderStack sets a maximum limit of 4 MB per batch request and 32 KB per call.**
-----

#### Accepted Fields

|**Field**|**Type**|**Presence**|**Description**|
|-----|-----|-----|-----|
|`batch`|Array|Required|Sets the user ID in cases where there is no unique identifier for the user in the database.|
|`context`|Object|Optional|Dictionary of information that provides context about a message. It is not directly related to the API call.|
|`integrations`|Object|Optional|Contains the list of destinations to be enabled or disabled for the call.|

> The `context` and `integrations` fields in the `batch` call are the same as in case of other calls. However, **they are merged** with the `context` or `integrations` (if any) fields in each of the calls included within `batch`.
-------

item.description:
The **RudderStack HTTP API** lets you track your customer event data and route it to your desired destinations. 

> We recommend using the RudderStack SDKs for automatic tagging of the user identity as well as context, batching the events, and leveraging the retry functionality in case of failure. **However, if you cannot use our SDKs, it is possible to send your event data using the HTTP API**.
--------

## RudderStack Data Plane

To send HTTP requests, you should have a RudderStack server configured with your workspace token. Please refer to [**this section**](https://docs.rudderstack.com/getting-started/installing-and-setting-up-rudderstack) for installing and setting up RudderStack.

> For more information on the RudderStack Data Plane, refer to our [**documentation**](https://docs.rudderstack.com/get-started/rudderstack-architecture#data-plane-architecture).
-------  

>**Note**: RudderStack's HTTP server should be accessible from your HTTP client.
-----

> A workspace token is unique to your RudderStack workspace.
-----

![Workspace Token](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/59817155/126443739-c79ba47e-e0f9-4f2e-9ebb-f03d6042e94a.png)

## Postman Collection

Import the Postman collection using this [**URL**](https://www.postman.com/collections/480307c55ad2b9dd4e27) and edit the variables `source_write_key` and `data_plane_url` with your source write key and the RudderStack Data Plane URL. Now you can test all supported requests.

> **Note**: If you are using RudderStack Cloud, the Data Plane URL should be set to: **https://hosted.rudderlabs.com**.
------

## HTTP Authorization

RudderStack uses Basic Authentication for authenticating all the HTTP requests. The HTTP Basic Authentication requires a username and password, where:

* Your source write key is the username, and
* An empty string (`" "`) is the password.

A source write key is the write key associated with the source you have configured in RudderStack, as shown:

![Source Write Key](https://gblobscdn.gitbook.com/assets%2F-Lq5Ea6fHVg3dSxMCgyQ%2F-MdWwuzSa0-3wrwkgnpT%2F-MdWwzPaX4Q0SVIeePn8%2FScreen%20Shot%202021-07-01%20at%205.27.53%20PM.png?alt=media&token=15c7f42a-589f-4c1a-b2ae-bac781bf5b88)

For example, if your `writeKey` is `1Xk5DChfJAol3xtW7qNnK1apo5p`, then your HTTP request must have the following HTTP header:

`Authorization: Basic MVhrNURDaGZKQW9sM3h0VzdxTm5LMWFwbzVwOg==`

You can refer to this sample [**Basic Auth header generator**](https://www.blitter.se/utils/basic-authentication-header-generator/) to verify your header.

## HTTP Responses

RudderStack returns a `200` response for successful API requests. It returns a `400` response for invalid requests along with an appropriate error message in the response.

Some responses to the invalid requests include:

* Request size too large (refer to the **Maximum Allowed Request Size** section below for more information)
* Invalid JSON
* Missing Authorization Header
* Invalid Authorization Header

## Request Size

RudderStack allows a maximum of 32KB message size per call, while the `batch` API request allows a maximum call size of 4MB. If these limits are exceeded, RudderStack responds with a `400 Bad Request` response.

item.name: Access Tokens
item.description:
To consume all the public RudderStack APIs, you will need access to them. This guide details the steps required to generate an access token and the operations associated with it.

> Read more about RudderStack's Transformations feature [here](https://rudderstack.com/docs/transformations/#adding-a-transformation).

* * *

## Permissions

The [**RudderStack Cloud**](https://app.rudderstack.com/) users who have the Read/Write or Admin privileges can create their own access tokens and use them.

## Operations on the Access Token

To use all the public RudderStack APIs, you can create your own Access Token by following the steps below:

*   Log into your [**RudderStack dashboard**](https://app.rudderstack.com/).
*   Click on the [**profile**](https://app.rudderstack.com/profile) tab in the left panel of the dashboard and choose the [**Personal Access Tokens**](https://app.rudderstack.com/profile/tokens) option, as shown:
    

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/59817155/132644830-6542369b-94ae-4af6-b3bb-c1432e64cd2c.png)

*   Then, click on **Generate new token** option. Enter the token **name** in the popup and click on **Generate**, as shown:
    

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/59817155/132644851-12db3095-6ea5-423f-aa0c-5890f8d0e62f.png)

*   You will then be able to see and copy the access token, as shown:
    

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/59817155/132644881-879f4b14-064b-4168-9e52-69707480926e.png)

> Make sure you copy the generated token. **You won't be able to see it again**.

* * *

*   To delete an existing token, click on the corresponding **Delete** option next to that token, and confirm by clicking on the **Yes, delete** button.
*   To delete all the existing tokens, click on the **Revoke all** button on the top right and confirm, as shown:
    

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/59817155/132644930-ce2124ac-897c-44d5-b51e-8201e03c1a6c.png)

## Contact Us

For any queries on generating or using the access tokens to consume the RudderStack APIs, you can start a conversation on our [**Slack**](https://resources.rudderstack.com/join-rudderstack-slack) channel.

item.name: Transformations API
Transformations

request.description:
This request creates a transformation and gets its object as a response.

The following table highlights the query parameters when making the API request.

## Query Parameters

|Parameter|Type|Presence|Description|
|------|------|------|------|
|`publish`|Boolean|Optional| By default, this flag is set to `false`. If set to `true`, it publishes your transformation to the latest version and the code is made live for the incoming traffic.|

## Body Parameters

The following table highlights the different body parameters when making the API request.

|Parameter|Type|Presence|Description|
|------|------|------|------|
|`events`|Object|Optional|You can pass an array of JSON events to be tested for your code.|
|`destinationIds`|Array|Optional|You can pass an array of `destinationIds` that you wish to connect with this transformation. You can connect only if `publish` is set to `true`.|
|`name`|String|Required|Name of the transformation that you wish to create.|
|`code`|String|Required|The transformation code goes here.|
|`description`|String|Optional|The description of the transformation goes here.|


## Creating a Transformation
You can create a transformation in one of the following ways:

- `publish: true` - In this case, RudderStack maintains two copies of the transformation. Among these, one is published and the other is used for revisions. You can connect the published transformation to a destination and its code is made live for incoming traffic.

- `publish: false` - In this case, RudderStack only creates revisions for the transformation. This means that you cannot connect any destinations to the transformation and it cannot be used for any incoming event traffic. 

> **Note**: If you wish to publish some revisions of transformations you can do so using the **Publish API** (refer below).
----

This request creates and publishes a transformation.

You can create a transformation in one of the following ways:

- `publish: true` - In this case, RudderStack maintains two copies of the transformer. Among these, one is published and the other is used for revisions. You can connect the published version to a destination and its code is made live for incoming traffic.

- `publish: false` - In this case, RudderStack only creates revisions for the transformation. This means that you cannot connect any destinations to the transformation and it cannot be used for any incoming event traffic.
This request gets all the **published transformations** for a particular workspace.

response.name: List All Transformations
response.body:
{
    "transformations": [
        {
            "id": "1vIcaq43otQJoKK5GpnC7YLsv1t",
            "versionId": "1vIcar0qoEdoL1Tk1pszUg9vEmG",
            "name": "Transformation 5",
            "description": "",
            "code": "export function transformEvent(event) { return event; }",
            "codeVersion": "1",
            "createdAt": "2021-07-14T08:58:29.708Z",
            "updatedAt": "2021-07-14T08:58:29.708Z",
            "destinations": []
        },
        {
            "id": "1vIdrehlhNup8ecEkXo9GJr2zzf",
            "versionId": "1vIdrdZEEr3t63Nw1rHqKGkyjXw",
            "name": "Transformation 1",
            "description": "",
            "code": "export function transformEvent(event) { return event; }",
            "codeVersion": "1",
            "createdAt": "2021-07-14T09:08:56.680Z",
            "updatedAt": "2021-07-14T09:08:56.680Z",
            "destinations": []
        }
    ]
}

request.description: This request retrieves the published transformations from the specified transformation `id`.

This request updates a transformation by creating a new revision. If the `publish` flag is set is `true`,  the code becomes live for the event traffic. If the `publish` flag is `false` , it only creates a new revision for that transformation without publishing it.

## Query Parameters

|Parameter|Type|Presence|Description|
|------|------|------|------|
|`publish`|Boolean|Optional| By default, this flag is set to `false`. If set to `true`, it publishes your transformation and the code is made live for the incoming traffic.|

## Body Parameters

The following table highlights the different body parameters when making this API request.

|Parameter|Type|Presence|Description|
|------|------|------|------|
|`events`|Object|Optional|You can pass an array of JSON events to test your code.|
|`code`|String|Update the code of your existing transformation.|
|`description`|String|Optional|Updated description of the transformation goes here.|

response.name: Update a Transformation
response.body:
{
    "id": "1vIdrehlhNup8ecEkXo9GJr2zzf",
    "versionId": "1vIhg7EnRFP2nTf0CbnSbK58FgB",
    "name": "Updated transformation",
    "description": "Updated description",
    "code": "export function transformEvent(event) { return event; }",
    "codeVersion": "1",
    "createdAt": "2021-07-14T09:40:18.946Z",
    "updatedAt": "2021-07-14T09:40:18.946Z"
}

request.description: This request updates a transformation by creating a new revision and publishes it so that the code is live for all the incoming event traffic.

response.name: Update and Publish a Transformation
response.body:
{
    "id": "1vIdrehlhNup8ecEkXo9GJr2zzf",
    "versionId": "1vIi5aGX27kXY60eNl5dixyNCET",
    "name": "Updated sample transformation",
    "description": "Updated sample transformation ready to be published",
    "code": "export function transformEvent(event) { return event; }",
    "codeVersion": "1",
    "createdAt": "2021-07-14T09:43:40.628Z",
    "updatedAt": "2021-07-14T09:43:40.628Z"
}

request.description:
This request deletes a transformation associated with the specified ID.

> Note that RudderStack does not delete a transformation revision.
------

query.description: Gets the number of objects in your array. By default, it always returns the first 5 objects.
You can get all the versions in the ascending order if you pass ASC as the value, or in the descending order if DESC is passed.

request.description:
This request gets all your transformation revisions by passing an ID.

#### Query Parameters

|**Key**|**Type**|**Presence**|**Description**|
|------|------|------|------|
|`count`|Number|Optional|Gets the number of objects in your array. By default, it always returns the first 5 objects.|
|`orderBy`|String|Optional|You can get all the versions in the ascending order if you pass `ASC` as the value, or in the descending order if `DESC` is passed.|

response.name: Get All Transformation Revisions

query.description: Gets the number of objects in your array. By default, it always returns the first 5 objects.
You can get all the versions in the ascending order if you pass ASC as the value, or in the descending order if DESC is passed.

request.description: This request fetches a single transformation revision.

item.description:
RudderStack Transformations let you write custom JavaScript code that allows you transform your events into a destination-specific format.

The following table explains the different fields in the transformer payload:

|Field|Type|Requirement|Description|
|:----|:----|:----|:----|
|`name`|String|Required|Sets the name of the transformer.|
|`description`|String|Optional|Gives a description of the transformer.|
|`code`|String|Optional|Refers to the user-defined code that maps the source events to the destinations as defined by the user.|
|`codeVersion`|String|Optional|This is an integer data always set to version 1 for the API calls.|
|`createdAt`|Date|Optional|Refers to the timestamp of the transformer when it is created.|
|`updatedAt`|Date|Optional|Refers to the timestamp of the transformer when it is updated.|
|`versionId`|String|Optional|Maintains a version of the transformer every time it is updated.|
|`workspaceId`|Object|Optional|The workspace ID on which the transformation is created.|
|`destinations`|Array|Optional|List of all the destination IDs to which your transformation is connected.|

request.description:
This request creates a transformation library and gets the corresponding JSON object as a response.

#### Body Parameters

|**Parameter**|**Type**|**Presence**|**Description**|
|-----|-----|-----|-----|
|`name`|String|Required|Name of the transformation library that you wish to create.|
|`code`|String|Required|Code the transformation library goes here.|
|`description`|String|Optional|The description of the transformation library goes here.|

response.name: Create a library
response.body:
{
    "id": "1vIo8AHR6nBoUOj0yrpQ6tdOS9o",
    "versionId": "1vIo87EmOpqnB1avdnmXHt5Yu9E",
    "name": "Transformation Library 3",
    "description": "Some library description",
    "code": "    export default function cube(x) { return x * x * x; }",
    "createdAt": "2021-07-14T10:33:21.908Z",
    "updatedAt": "2021-07-14T10:33:21.908Z",
    "importName": "transformationLibrary3"
}

request.description:
This request creates and publishes a transformation library.

#### Query Parameters

|**Parameter**|**Type**|**Presence**|**Description**|
|-----|-----|-----|-----|
|`publish`|Boolean|Optional|By default, this flag is set to `false`. If set to `true`, this option is used to publish your transformation library to its latest version.|


> **Note**: The `publish` flag for a transformation library works the same way as a transformation.
-----

#### Body Parameters

|**Parameter**|**Type**|**Presence**|**Description**|
|-----|-----|-----|-----|
|`name`|String|Required|Name of the transformation library that you wish to create.|
|`code`|String|Required|Code the transformation library goes here.|
|`description`|String|Optional|The description of the transformation library goes here.|

response.name: Create and Publish a Library
response.body:
{
    "id": "1vIoJSpWlMAomjFUD0nhZOguZmG",
    "versionId": "1vIoJVVMJTUbMWDe44H52kOwZ41",
    "name": "Sample Transformation Library",
    "description": "Library description",
    "code": "    export default function cube(x) { return x * x * x; }",
    "createdAt": "2021-07-14T10:34:51.592Z",
    "updatedAt": "2021-07-14T10:34:51.592Z",
    "importName": "sampleTransformationLibrary"
}

request.description: This request fetches all the published transformation libraries.

response.name: List All Libraries
response.body:
{
    "libraries": [
        {
            "id": "1vIoJSpWlMAomjFUD0nhZOguZmG",
            "versionId": "1vIoJVVMJTUbMWDe44H52kOwZ41",
            "name": "Sample Transformation Library",
            "description": "Library description",
            "code": "    export default function cube(x) { return x * x * x; }",
            "createdAt": "2021-07-14T10:34:51.606Z",

        },
        {
            "id": "1vIomrQz5z9bkDcPQGAUGiFLl9N",
            "versionId": "1vIomqeY6mWqDO297kDp6f0MsUh",
            "name": "Sample Transformation Library 1",
            "description": "Library description",
            "code": "    export default function cube(x) { return x * x * x; }",
            "createdAt": "2021-07-14T10:38:45.823Z",
            "updatedAt": "2021-07-14T10:38:45.823Z",
            "importName": "sampleTransformationLibrary1"
        }
    ]
}

request.description: Retrieves a single published transformation library based on the specified `id`.

response.name: Retrieve a Single Library
response.body:
{
    "id": "1vIoJSpWlMAomjFUD0nhZOguZmG",
    "versionId": "1vIoJVVMJTUbMWDe44H52kOwZ41",
    "name": "Sample Transformation Library",
    "description": "Library description",
    "code": "    export default function cube(x) { return x * x * x; }",
    "createdAt": "2021-07-14T10:34:51.606Z",
    "updatedAt": "2021-07-14T10:34:51.606Z",
    "importName": "sampleTransformationLibrary"
}

request.description:
This request lets you update the code and description of the transformation library by specifying its `id`.

> **Note**: You **cannot** change the name of the transformation library using this request.
----

#### Body Parameters

|**Parameter**|**Type**|**Presence**|**Description**|
|-----|-----|-----|-----|
|`description`|String|Optional|The updated description of the transformation library goes here.|
|`code`|String|Required|The updated code the transformation library goes here.|

response.name: Update a Library
response.body:
{
    "id": "1vIoJSpWlMAomjFUD0nhZOguZmG",
    "versionId": "1vIpxntV2xzGc05H8trHmrLVp0W",
    "name": "Sample Transformation Library",
    "description": "Updated library code from cube function to a sum function",
    "code": "    export default function sum(x) { return x + x; }",
    "createdAt": "2021-07-14T10:48:25.623Z",
    "updatedAt": "2021-07-14T10:48:25.623Z",
    "importName": "sampleTransformationLibrary"
}

request.description:
This request lets you update the code and description of the transformation library by specifying its `id` and gives you the option of publishing this library.

> **Note**: Updating the library with the `publish` option has the same flow as that of the transformations.

#### Query Parameters

|**Parameter**|**Type**|**Presence**|**Description**|
|-----|-----|-----|-----|
|`publish`|Boolean|Optional|By default, this flag is set to `false`. If set to `true`, this option is used to publish your transformation library to its latest version.|

#### Body Parameters

|**Parameter**|**Type**|**Presence**|**Description**|
|-----|-----|-----|-----|
|`description`|String|Optional|The updated description of the transformation library goes here.|
|`code`|String|Optional|The updated code of the transformation library goes here.|

response.name: Update and Publish a Library
response.body:
{
    "id": "1vIoJSpWlMAomjFUD0nhZOguZmG",
    "versionId": "1vIqcGyY4qHtrnPJGFwOFDMQ6Zk",
    "name": "Sample Transformation Library",
    "description": "Updated library description",
    "code": "    export default function sum(x) { return x + x; }",
    "createdAt": "2021-07-14T10:53:47.425Z",
    "updatedAt": "2021-07-14T10:53:47.425Z",
    "importName": "sampleTransformationLibrary"
}

query.description: (Optional) If you want a specific number of versions for the library ID, pass this key. By default, this request always returns the first 5 objects.

(Optional) To get the library versions in the ascending or descending order, pass this key. By default, the request always returns the ascending order of versions by considering the time of creation of the library version.

request.description:
This request retrieves all the library revisions for the specified library `id`.

#### Query Parameters

|**Parameter**|**Type**|**Presence**|**Description**|
|-----|-----|-----|-----|
|`count`|Number|Optional|If you want a specific number of library versions for the specified library ID, pass this parameter. By default, the request always returns the first 5 versions.|
|`orderBy`|String|Optional|To get the library versions in the ascending or descending order, pass this key. By default, the request always returns the ascending order of versions by considering the time of creation of the library version.|

response.name: List All Library Revisions

item.name: Test & Publish API

request.description:
This request tests any transformation or library revisions.

#### Body Parameters

|**Parameter**|**Type**|**Presence**|**Description**|
|-----|-----|-----|-----|
|`versionId`|String|Required|The transformation `versionId` to be published.|
|`testInput`|String|Optional|Array of JSON objects in a string format.|
|`transformations`|Array|Optional|An array of objects with the property as `versionId` and `testInput`.|
|`libraries`|Array|Optional|An array of objects with the property as the library `versionId`.|

#### Note

This API lets you test your transformation and library revisions.

>**Output response shows successful and failed results**
--------

This request publishes any transformation or library revisions.

#### Body Parameters

|**Parameter**|**Type**|**Presence**|**Description**|
|-----|-----|-----|-----|
|`versionId`|String|Required|The transformation `versionId` to be published.|
|`testInput`|String|Optional|Array of JSON objects in a string format.|
|`transformations`|Array|Optional|An array of objects with the property as `versionId` and `testInput`.|
|`libraries`|Array|Optional|An array of objects with the property as the library `versionId`.|

#### Note

This API lets you publish your transformation and library revisions. However, also note the following:

* You can choose to publish a transformation revision without the libraries.
* You can also choose to publish some library revisions without publishing the transformations.


>**Note**: Whenever you call the `publish` API, we run tests in our server to ensure you don't save any transformation/library code that can lead to any exceptions. 
**In case your publish action fails, verify if the transformation code and the libraries it is referring to are correct.**
---------

item.description:
As an end-user, you can create a transformation/library and perform several edits on it. **Note that publishing is optional when you create a transformation or a library**. Suppose you perform several edits or revisions on a transformation. RudderStack always takes the latest update as the published version, creates a copy of the older versions, and saves them as revisions. Now suppose that you've created 7 to 8 such revisions of your transformation and now want to use the second revision for transforming your event traffic. You can do this by leveraging RudderStack's **Publish API**. #### Publish Payload |**Parameter**|**Type**|**Presence**|**Description**| |-----|-----|-----|-----| |`transformations`|Array|Optional (if `libraries` is present)|You can pass an array of multiple transformation `versionId` that you want to publish.| |`libraries`|Array|Optional (if `transformations` is present)|You can pass an array of multiple library `versionId` that you want to publish.|
>**Note**: Any one of `transformations` or `libraries` must be present in the payload to make a successful `publish` call. ------

**Transformations** is one of RudderStack's key features. It allows you to leverage custom JavaScript functions to transform your source event payload into a destination-specific format. RudderStack Transformations can be used across your Event Stream, Warehouse Actions, and Cloud Extract pipelines, allowing you to implement a variety of use-cases, like: - Filtering or sampling events. - Enriching events by implementing static logic or leveraging an external API. - Cleaning data by removing unnecessary bits. - Masking or removing sensitive PII information in the events to ensure data privacy. - Aggregating / rolling-up data at a micro-batch level. - Implementing external actions on the events by means of an API.
> Our [**Sample User Transformations**](https://github.com/rudderlabs/sample-user-transformers) GitHub repository contains some useful templates that you can use to create your own user transformations. ____ For more information on this feature and how to use it, visit our [**docs**](https://rudderstack.com/docs/transformations/#adding-a-transformation). ## What is the Transformations API? RudderStack's Transformations API allows you to create, read, update and delete transformations and libraries programmatically. ## Authentication The Transformations API is authenticated via Basic Authentication. You can authenticate your account by including your email address as the username and the secret access token in the password field under the **Authorization** tab. Any API requests made without the authentication will fail. > **Important**: It is mandatory to generate your access token before you make any API calls. To generate the access token, refer to the **Access Token** section. ---- You can also pass your access token in the authorization header directly, as shown: ``` Authorization: Basic {Base64Encoded(:)} ``` For example, if your email address is `username@domain.com` and the generated access token is `1pHxUIA3jmxS2ip01zY696F80j7`, then the header will be: ``` Basic {Base64Encoded(username@domain.com:1pHxUIA3jmxS2ip01zY696F80j7)} ```
> **Important**: To make success API requests, all the endpoints covered in this guide must include this header. ----

item.name: Tracking Plan API

request.description:
Creates a tracking plan with the provided schema rules for `identify`/`group` events.

> An empty tracking plan can be created with no rules.

---

Query Params:

**overwriteEvents=false**: While creating tracking plan events if already existing event in workspace is present in request payload, we make a choice not to overwrite event and hence request fails.

> By default this flag set to false

**overwriteEvents=true**: If we encounter already existing event in workspace, updates existing event. As a result, all tracking plans connected to this event gets updated.

For Example: Plan P1 connected to event E1. New plan P2 is created with event E1 as payload. E1 gets updated and its connected plans namely P1 will have latest code of E1

response.name: Create Tracking Plan with overwriteEvents set to True

request.description:
Updates existing tracking plan with provided schema rules for identify/group/events.

> Supports only partial Update  
> For Ex: Events E1,E2 connected to plan P1. By passing only E2 in payload to update E2 doesn't mean that E1 connection to plan P1 will be gone

> Tracking plan name change is not supported

**overwriteEvents=false**: While creating tracking plan events if already existing event in workspace is present in request payload, we make a choice not to overwrite event and hence request fails.

> By default this flag set to false

**overwriteEvents=true**: If we encounter already existing event in workspace, updates existing event. As a result, all tracking plans connected to this event gets updated.

---

response.name: Update Tracking Plan with overwriteEvents set to false
Update Tracking Plan overwriteEvents set to true

request.description:
Creates/updates a tracking plan with provided schema rules for identify/group/events.

> Tracking plan display_name is required field in body json

> Plan by given name already exists, updates the tracing plan  
> Plan by given name does not exists, creates a new tracking plan 

**overwriteEvents=false**: While creating tracking plan events if already existing event in workspace is present in request payload, we make a choice not to overwrite event and hence request fails.

> By default this flag set to false

**overwriteEvents=true**: If we encounter already existing event in workspace, updates existing event. As a result, all tracking plans connected to this event gets updated.

For Example: Plan P1 connected to event E1. New plan P2 is created with event E1 as payload. E1 gets updated and its connected plans namely P1 will have latest code of E1

---

response.name: Upsert Tracking Plan: overwrite set to false
Upsert Tracking Plan
Upsert Tracking Plan: create tracking plan (given new name) overwriteEvents set to true

item.name: Get the Tracking Plan by ID

request.description:
Fetches the tracking plan by its ID and the linked events, identify, and group schemas.

> With an optional query parameter `version` number, you can get the previous tracking plan versions.

---

response.name: Get the Tracking Plan by ID

request.description:
Fetches all the tracking plans present in the authenticated user workspace.

---

item.name: Create Events in the User Workspace

request.description:
This request creates new events in the authenticated user workspace.

A few things to note:

* The event name should be unique per user workspace

* You cannot update the event name.

---

This request fetches all the events present in the authenticated user workspace irrespective of whether they are linked to the tracking plan or not.

> Event ID and version are autogenerated.

---

response.name: Events

request.description:
This request updates the existing event and the corresponding tracking plans linked to that event.

> An update to the event description does not update the version of the linked tracking plans.
---

item.name: Link Events  to a Tracking Plan

request.description:
Use this API to link the event/s to a particular tracking plan. 

---

item.name: Unlink Events from a Tracking Plan

request.description:
This API unlinks the event ID list from given tracking plan.

---

item.name: Get All Events Linked to a Tracking Plan (Including Deleted and Active Events)

request.description:
This request fetches all the events linked to the given tracking plan, including both deleted and active events.

> The deleted events are referred to as unlinked events.

---

response.name: All events

item.name: Create/Update Identify Rules for the Tracking Plan

request.description:
* If the identify rules do not exist, this request creates the rules and links them to the given tracking plan.
* If the identify rules exist, it updates the existing identify rules.

---

item.name: Delete Identify Rules for the Tracking Plan

request.description:
This request deletes the identify rules linked to the given tracking plan.

---

item.name: Create/Update Group Rules for the Tracking Plan

request.description:
* If the group rules do not exist, this request creates the group rules and links them to the given tracking plan.
* If the group rules exists, this request updates them.

---

item.name: Delete Group Rules for Tracking plan

request.description:
This request deletes the group rules linked to the given tracking plan.

---

This request creates/updates configuration for given source id.

---

This request fetches configuration for given source id.

> With an optional query parameter `version` number, you can get the previous configuration versions.

---

Use this API to connect tracking plan to source

> If source is already linked to plan, this request overrides existing plan connection

> Supports create or update for only one connection at a time

---

This request fetches all sources connected to given tracking plan

---

response.name: List of connections to Tracking Plan

request.description:
Deletes connection between given source id and tracking plan id

---

item.description:
This collection contains a list of the supporting **Data Governance API** calls and models with relevant examples.

## Tracking Plan Model

| **Attribute** | **Type** | **Description** | **Requirement** |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| `name` | ID | Autogenerated name | Read-only |
| `display_name` | String | Display name of the plan | Required |
| `rules` | Rules | Schema rules for the plan | Optional |
| `version` | Version | Current version of the plan | Read-only |
| `create_time` | DateTime | Time of creation | Read-only |
| `update_time` | DateTime | Time of update | Read-only |

## Rules Model

| Attribute | Type | Description | Requirement |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| `events` | Array\[object\] | Rules applied to the `track` calls | Optional |
| `identify` | Object | Rules applied to the `identify` calls | Optional |
| `group` | Object | Rules applied to the `group` calls | Optional |

## Events Model

| Attribute | Type | Description | Requirement |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| `name` | String | Event Name | Required |
| `description` | String | Event description | Optional |
| `rules` | JSON | Rules applied to the event | Required |

# Access Tokens

You can obtain the access token by following the documentation [here](https://rudderstack.com/docs/transformations/api-access-token/).

| Authentication Params | Type | Description |
| --- | --- | --- |
| `username` | String | Email ID of the user |
| `password` | String | Access token obtained from the above docs |
